reviewText:
Powered by id's Quake 3 technology and released in 2001, Gray Matter's Return to Castle Wolfenstein features a tremendous campaign spanning over 25 levels across numerous missions.  Soaking rich in atmosphere and modded to support current widescreen resolutions, the campaign is an excellent precursor to 2014's Wolfenstein A New Order.

Despite it's age the game plays perfectly.  Combat at times is brutal and difficult.  The AI is a great challenge and surpasses many a modern title.  Weapons are inventive and feature what be may be the most well implemented chain gun ever to grace a video game.   The game falls far short of New Order's stealth mechanics but the combat is so over the top satisfying that I doubt anyone would notice.

Gray Matter Interactive developed Return to Castle Wolfenstein.  The studio was acquired by Activision in 2002 and later merged into Treyarch of Call of Duty fame.

Return to Castle Wolfenstein; a true classic, a phenomenal FPS that has aged well and plays well on modern systems.

RTCW is a fun game and has aged well.

The premise of the story is very interesting. It centers around the Nazis' interest in the occult during WWII. While the story isn't the game's strongest point, it is satisfactory and never takes away from the gameplay. I appreciated the various letters that you find lying around during the game; they really add to the game's atmosphere.

Despite the game's age, the graphics are still good, in my opinion. By 2001 standards, they are exceptional.

The Quake 3 engine not only provides decent graphics, but, more importantly, makes for an awesome FPS combat experience. The weapons are great, and your character's movement is smooth. Combat is the game's main focus and without a doubt its strongest point.

The enemy A.I. is tough. I played the game on Bring em on! (the normal" difficulty) and died several times during my playthrough. However

reviewText:
Return to Castle Wolfenstein is supposedly a sort of remake of Wolfenstein 3D, but I don't know how you can have a remake of Wolfenstein 3D where you don't get to fight and kill a mech-clad Hitler.

RtCW is all good fun when you're fighting Nazis. Basic Nazis, elite Nazi ladies, and the what have yous. Where it loses me entirely is when it does the Monster Mash. The first mission is great! Fighting your way through Where Eagles Dare (a classic) and feeling like a boss. Then you get to mission 2. And now you're facing skeletons with swords and shields. For ♥♥♥♥'s sake, the most basic, stereotypical video game enemy possible. And yes, I am complaining about that in a game where you fight NAZIS.

But that's the thing, isn't it? I wanted to fight Nazis. I was playing Wolfenstein, and it turned into medieval DOOM with Germans. The final boss is an undead guy with a sword. Quite a step down from Hitler in a mech suit, I can tell you that. And sure, Wolf3D definitely had zombies. But they were experiments created by a Mengele-type guy. And they were basically just regular Nazis, but with an extra arm in the middle so that they could point their gun at you quicker than you could at them. There are electricity-shooting legless monster things in RtCW that the Nazis did create, and they're pretty cool. The game does a great job of building tension with these guys, and when they're not leaping into your face and being ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t they add a fun level of depth to their levels. But then you also have to deal with Super Soldiers, who are also sciencey, but ultimately boring.

Don't get me wrong, here. The majority of the game has you just fighting Nazis. Snipers are awesome and paratroopers are awesome and the extra-skillful leather-clad ladies are awesome, and... well, the guys with flamethrowers suck. But luckily there aren't many of them in the game.

The level design is very good. Each mission looks and feels different. In one you'll be sneaking around a wooded area, in another you'll be sniping through a snowstorm. In one mission you'll be fighting from a cable car as you descend from Castle Wolfenstein, in another you'll be infiltrating secret Nazi labs, and in still another you'll be escorting a tank through a town. There are plenty of secrets to find... at times. After you leave Castle Wolfenstein, they seem to just stop existing for several missions. It's a bit of a bummer, to be honest.

The pre-mission cutscenes are dull, I'm not gonna lie to you. A fat guy behind a desk far away from our protagonist speaks with some suits as slow and boringly as possible (not even having Tony Jay voice the fat guy saves these scenes). I also found that the music drowned out half of the other sounds in the game, making stealth tougher and making it impossible to overhear conversations that you're meant to overhear. Make sure to turn that option down a good deal.

The guns feel good when you're fighting humans. Otherworldly creatures often take too many bullets and don't react enough to being shot, leading one to wonder whether you're even damaging them at all.

So I like it. I do recommend it. But I wouldn't blame you for using console cheats to go invincible or skip levels when you have to deal with doofy skeletons and anything else that just fills you with apathy. And if there's a mod out there that replaces the final boss with Wolf3D's mech suit Hitler (in all of his pixely sprite glory), I'd suggest getting it. And if there isn't, I'd suggest making it.

reviewText:
Although released 15 years ago, Return to Castle Wolfenstein still packs a punch. Do note, however, that installing the game is not enough to have it run properly under newer systems - there is a guide available on Steam that tells us what patch to download and what files to overwrite. Once it is done, RoTW can be enjoyed even in the HD resolution!

The story of Wolfenstein has always been about Nazis and the occult. Blazkowicz, our hero, now faces some pretty gruesome monsters - beside eliminating soldiers we have lots of undead warriors here, plus, we get to see how Wilhelm Strasse's Übersoldat project unfolds. The Lopers are pretty nasty creatures - they are cyborgs whose lower body has completely been amputated and replaced with some sort of generators. Thanks to them and the undead creatures encountered in the labs, crypts, RoTW's atmosphere becomes great and creepy at times.

This is a classic shooter i.e. you shoot first then ask questions later. There are no keys to collect - just shoot everybody in your sight in order to proceed. Classic also means there are several hidden areas with lots of golden bars and chalices hidden throughout most of the levels. Finding all of them can be quite the challenge! While the game is old and has dated graphics the environments can still be appreciated. I still remember how critics marvelled at the flamethrower's effect which was one of a kind at the time.

I only have two complaints about RoTW - first, it misses a shotgun. There should at least be one weapon that is efficient during close encounters. Second, there are some levels where the emphasis is on using stealth playstyle. This is not executed very well always - sometimes you do not know what the reason was for the Germans to raise the alarm.

RoTW is a classic and should be played as such! Thanks to the great community there are means to run it on modern PCs and reminisce during its roughly 8-hour long campaign.

reviewText:
RtcW is a game from yesteryear. Back before the days of regenerating health and scripted sequences. When the Quake 3 engine was still king and everyone still waited for Duke Nukem Forever.

Return to Castle Wolfenstein's most memorable element to me is its simplicity. It is very similar to Wolfy 3D in that you basically do two things in this game: Kill Nazis and find treasure. Infact it is to the game's benefit as it has aged startlingly well for a game from 2001. It encorporated elements like secret areas, treasure, eating food to restore your health etc, and added slightly more fantastical designs like mutants and zombies. RtcW is more linear than the previous game, but it has extremely good pacing and map design. You uncover shortcuts back to prior areas, and always feel in control in gunfights.

It's a shame RtcW isn't talked about as often as other games from it's era, since it is one of the best games Id ever published. A game that is just as epic as the name it carries.

GET THIS GAME!!!  Even if you didn't grow up with RTCW (I didn't), you will thoroughly enjoy this game.  RTCW has LOTS of levels with varied environments, from secret Nazi labs, rocket bases, towns, haunted crypts, and even Castle Wolfenstein itself. The graphics themselves are nicely detailed.  Some textures on the terrain are what you'd expect from early 2000's, but the characters themselves are actually very nice looking.

Most of your guns are from the appropriate WW2 era, but you get some interesting ones like the flamethrower, tesla gun, and venom machine gun; you'll probably stick to the mp40 and sten 80% of the game though.

Only complaint with the game is that it might break it when adjusting the screen resolution higher than 1024 width, so be sure to visit pcgamingwiki to figure how to adjust the resolution and you'll have NO problem at all!

All in all I'm impressed with how well this game has held up and entertained me after over a decade of not even knowing about it.

reviewText:
Return to Castle Wolfenstein is a sequel to Wolfenstein 3D fo sorts. Well, of prequel. Or reboot. After 9 years or so and technology advancment you shouldn't expect things to be same anyway. It's a WW2 shooter from 2001, made by id and Gray Matter and Nerve Software (one handled singleplayer, another handled multiplayer), it runs on Quake 3 engine. And well, was released in the beggining of those horrible times when every second shooter was WW2 themed.
There also was Enemy Territory, a sort of stand-alone multiplayer expansion pack that is free. It's not included there, but you know, it's free.
It also had XBox and PS2 version, both with additional prologue level and new shotgun as weapon. XBox even has 2-player coop as far as I am aware. Worth tracking down.

Surprisingly, for id software title, this game on Steam works pretty fine. It just doesn't support widescreen, which I think can easily fix through config files or so. Check guides.

Well, if forget that multiplayer portion still tries to use master server that was shut down times ago. In all honesty, I didn't bother fixing it, I doubt that it has active enough player base nowdays. Multiplayer the main reason people were praising this game, but with free Enemy Territory around, I don't think anybody will be playing this now.

In this game you play as agent Blazkowicz, noted for his ability to infiltrate bases and infiltrate every nazi he meets. And you have to Return to Castle Woflenstein!
If forget that you already start inside it and it's not as pretty as your rose-tinted nostalgia glasses were telling you, so now you have to Unreturn to Castle Wolfenstein!
All while learning about occult stuff on your way out, which then excites people at headquarters enough to send you to every Nazi evil project in the world, to learn more. And to sabotage every possible invention that Nazi came up with. Which is fun, no complaints.

As for game itself, well, it's an early WW2 shooter. It was past Doom times when your movement was your defence, since pretty much every attack here is hitscan. It was also before regenerating and cover systems. It's just an early realistical FPS where your main defence is how fast can you react by headshotting soldier and where you can get into unfair situation where you randomly die due to random hitscan bullets and you can't do anything but to reload quicksave until you luckily pass it.

Thankfully, this FPS is one of those 2000s shooters that mix stealth and action instead of fighting straight on. You could lean left and right to peek around corner. You could just walk to sneak onto enemy. And you have knife that instakills if used on the back of unaware enemy with stab stab stab animation. You will also get silenced weapons that will help you. Oh yea, and pistols in this game are useless, don't bother.
Just don't think that Stealth is all that goodly done. It's on a weak side, somewhat, just enough to vary action up, to remove some soldiers before main action starts. It's not often required, outside of two mandatory stealth missions, that aren't as hard as worst examples in some other games. Just don't expect it to work well, you can always get noticed seemingly randomly.

And then once alarm goes on and everybody notices you, or if it was straight action mission to begin with, you get to shooting part. And well, it's mostly reaction game. Enemies who aren't exactly aware what and where are you don't react so fast, but once they do, they can be pain. Now, you can easily outshoot common enemies. You can even effectively snipe them at long distance, and it's fun. Or you can use grenade around corner, fun too. Awesome music helps.

Game gets to worst when you get to straight fight, when you can't sneak or ambush or take advantage of enviroment much. These are bad moments of gameplay. It gets worse if you meet tougher enemies in such situation. Unlike, say, enemies from Rise of The Triad, game that handles crowds of hitscan enemies, soldiers can shoot with no problem back while being shot at while screwing your aim off. And then game can have unfair situation, especially when you are on low health. Like, getting ambushed right while crawling up the ladder. Or second boss, Das Ubersoldat, immeditly hitscan-attacks you even before you can take cover or even check where you can take cover. Unless exploit his AI, mhm. Or just getting shot at by sniper in a foggy valley, where sniper is only barely visible from the fog, is placed behind tree, is on the hill somewhere on the side, and keeps dropping your aim off by shooting you succesfully. All yay quicksaves.

But hey, outside of shooting itself, game has nice exploration feel to it, despite being linear. Small detail spread over realistical, yet not painfully gray, levels. Secrets are placed through levels, nicely hidden. First mission, castle Wolfenstein, is especially awesome with all the secrets hidden. Graphics are nice. It also has plenty of less generic guns, like flamethrower or tesla gun.
I also didn't mention the very few parts of a game where you handle undead. It becomes something more simple here. Not great by itself, but helps to vary up.
Bosses aren't great. First one is good, second is hitscan bulletsponge, final one is bulletsponge that has harder time to kill you than anybody else.
Soundtrack is also awesome, improving atmosphere and actually helping you to get into mood required for playing this game.

Return of Castle Wolfenstein is pretty good when compared to other early WW2 shooters. It's a mix of not-so-strong stealths and not-so-strong action, which will give you fun when both of those are present. When it comes to parts with straight action, it gets as frustrating as expected, though.
Still better than Wolf3D. It is however amazingly overrated, while being more of meh.

reviewText:
This being one of the formative games of my teenage years, I expected to trip balls on nostalgia when playing this, and delete it and forget it. However, what I found was an incredibly solid and challenging shooter (and the best looking game from its era) that somehow made killing Nazis seem cool and different, despite being from 2001 - the eye of the WW2 shooter storm.

The secret to RTCW's success is solid core gameplay complimented by sound technical design, loads of atmosphere, and a thematically colourful and interactive world. The running and shooting all works very well, and the variety of weapons and enemy types all make for a compelling and exciting FPS. The stealth works, and the number of silenced weapons you are given allow the player the change their play-style from time to time. It's not a central feature, but it works well enough to compliment the game rather than detract from it, which is more than I expected.

But this all would mean little if it weren't for the layers draped over the framework.

The level design, while not always consistent in terms of level length or complexity, is more often than not interesting, and the variety of environments leaves the player feeling like they've experienced a great deal between the beginning and the end of the game. At its best, RTCW has multiple routes that the player can take, and plenty of secrets to uncover for the completionist. However, if one chooses to run and gun, the action is responsive and the enemies well-programmed and well-placed enough to compliment this play style as well.

The game is just dripping with atmosphere, and this is in no small part due to the fantastic sound design. The soundtrack is excellent, and on par with the classic Medal of Honor soundtracks from back when that name actually meant something. Since the narrative covers both battle-oriented military settings and creepy horror, tonally the music shifts frequently and dictates the level of tension in an individual mission, saturating the player with emotion before a single thing has happened - this is especially noticable in the creepier levels. The weapon sounds are similarly powerful and convey a sense of accuracy skewed just enough towards dramatic licence to give each shot a sense of fulfilling drama. A small but powerful feature is the changing sound of the gunfire as the enemies move further away - the crack of a nearby rifle gives way to a dull thud as they are fired in the distance, and enhances the tension of the battles as your brain is left to process the direction and distance of the shot, and you are immersed further into the world.

I found the voice acting to be delightfully tongue-in-cheek as the actors embrace the schlocky nature of the story and deliver their lines entertainingly, allowing the tone of the game to shift from moment to moment and lifting the game beyond a single note played ad infinitum.

I also was pleased with the in-game narrative dealt up to the player. Whilst there are a number of cutscenes that are not always that compelling, from level-to-level one can find a number of papers to read, or pick up on enemy conversations that are shockingly effective at rounding out the otherwise faceless goons that you plow through. One particular example is a conversation between and officer and a subordinate regarding a soldier that has been sent to the wine cellar to find some wine and has failed to return. As you venture around the level you can eventually hear some drunken singing, and you find the soldier in question staggering around one of the cellars. Not only does this give the NPCs some personality, but it also adds to the larger narrative, in which you are infiltrating a city in which there are a number of officers gathering for an event. You know how they're occupying themselves, and how they treat those around them, and it all adds up to make you feel like you're in a real place, which is essential for a game that is trying to sell you a fictional story of such outlandish proportions.

I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a solid shooter that is a cut above the rest in terms of imagination and personality.

P.S. In 2001, the leather-clad she-Nazis were the hottest things in gaming.

This is the third game in the Wolfenstein FPS series and fifth overall, released in 2001 and still playable even today, especially when compared with its preceding titles. (Not that they were bad, but they are considerably more dated.) Notably, it was developed by Gray Matter Studios, the same people behind Call of Duty's expansion pack United Offensive, with help from Nerve Software. iD only published it.


You play as Agent B.J. Blazkowicz, allied saboteur/spy/killing machine sent behind Nazi lines in World War II to...spy on the Nazis, specifically their paranormal activities. Unfortunately, you and your fellow agent-in-arms are captured and sent to the ubiquitous Castle Wolfenstein, where you must make your escape from the retrofitted dungeon.

The gameplay consists of making your way through levels and fulfilling objectives in any available manner you see fit - there's little hand-holding here. The levels are designed well and realistically, and even when they are linear it does a good job of convincing you otherwise, like in Half-Life.

Obviously there are Nazis in your way, and the number of weapons you get to choose from to kill them grow in accordance with the types you'll face. RTCW starts out akin to Call of Duty: World at War, but starts to resemble something more like that game's zombie mode pretty quickly and gets hairier from there.

The gunplay is great. Most of your weapons are generally useful, and you'll go from blasting troopers with a pilfered MP40 to silencing enemies with a silenced Sten that is both accurate and great fun to use, to roasting all manner of monsters with flamethrowers, Panzerschrecks and other big guns.


Interactivity isn't something you might expect from a game like this, but there's a good amount of it here. If an enemy sets off an alarm, you are capable of switching it off or simply destroying it to silence the alarm. You have a dedicated kick button, which lets you kick down doors and destroy objects with your mighty boot such as pictures of Hitler. Sometimes you must do things like destroying walls to continue. There are also secrets to be found in the levels, containing health, ammunition and sometimes Nazi treasure, akin to Wolf3D. The treasure does nothing but increase your treasure counter at the end-of-level score screen, but it's nice to grab it anyway.

There are two stealth levels that are nice ideas in theory but can prove frustrating and sometimes nonsensical in practice. Expect them to take a few tries, and don't be afraid to save. There are also ways to take stealthy approaches to the other missions, which are much more enjoyable.


The game has 3 difficulty settings, which are basically akin to the three hardest from Wolfenstein 3-D, the easiest setting from that game being removed. Playing on the middle difficulty, by the time you're nearing the end of the game it will prove rather challenging, with health and armor (especially armor) in short supply and a good amount of tough enemies...and those are just the regular mooks. There is no shame in quicksaving at certain points, or really ever but that's another matter. The AI is generally good, but not perfect (elite troops barrel rolling into walls come to mind), and while the final boss has the distiction of being easier than the levels preceding it you still need to watch yourself.

I have not played the multiplayer, but as far as I know it still has a relatively small amount of players. It primarily revolves around Axis players defending installations from Allied attackers, and is class-based. There is also a free multiplayer-only title out there called Enemy Territory that contains more features.

Overall I'd place RTCW as a slightly below-average length game, but with how atmospheric and difficult it can be you'll likely spend a decent chunk of time during your first playthrough.


RTCW runs off the Quake III Arena engine, which means fast default movement speeds and strafejumping when the levels permit it, but you can change it to a slower walk if you wish for a more realistic/difficult game. I'm sure this accounts for the graphics, as well, because when you max it out (and it's easy to do), the game looks very good, especially for a 2001 title! There is a fan patch to increase resolution sizes beyond 1028x760 and enable widescreen, but I personally couldn't get it to work and I didn't feel a need for it.

The plot, as befitting a Wolfenstein game of this period in the series, revolves around sci-fi/occult Nazi meddling with a bit of camp and a portion of horror. It can get outlandish at times, but the atmosphere the game presents only serves to complement it. If you're at all interested in secret Nazi stuff and alternate history, or blowing up secret Nazi stuff - especially with their own wunderwaffe - you'll probably like it.

Tony Jay is a voice actor here, and he's good as usual. That's worth quite a bit, at least.

While the game is good, I'm not sure about the Elite Guards. They're an all-woman enemy force, and while it's nice to see women taking action-oriented roles I could do without them wearing revealing outfits that I'm not sure are entirely practical. They serve as challenging enemies at least, but that's about it.

reviewText:
Something of a strangely forgotten classic amongst the variety of id games which have come out, and for the life of me I'm not entirely sure why.

Return to Castle Wolfenstein is a re-envisioning of the first popularized first-person shooter, Wolfenstein 3D. In it, you take on the role of an Allied soldier working his way through waves of nazi soldiers and supernatural elements that the SS have brought to life in order to turn the tides of WWII. It's irreverent, and is actually still quite a lot of fun.

I'm not sure how much of a community remains for the multiplayer element, but in its heyday this was one of the best multiplayer experiences one could have.

Effectively, this is one of the few FPS I can think of which straddles the need to hide behind cover of modern shooters for the complete insanity of running into mobs of enemies of older shooters. Worth a look if you want to have some fun.

reviewText: A classic. Fast paced and challenging gameplay paired up with a great atmosphere, and a sweet soundtrack. RtCW offers fantastic environments and an arsenal of awesome weapons. The weapons themselves look and feel perfect. The gun models in this game are easily among my favorites and the recoil mechanics work well, which makes shooting Nazis and the undead feel great. Return also features a leaning system which is helpful for scouting out enemy positions. The campaign contains very memorable missions, such as fighting zombies and ghosts in a spooky crypt below a German occupied village, or sneaking your way through a forest, stealthfully taking out German positions as you go, which ultimately leads to an enemy compound and after taking out all the guards, you hop into the back of a truck that takes you into the base. Return to Castle Wolfenstein puts you in a place where you truly feel all alone, isolated and stuck facing the odds. reviewText:
As I was scrolling through my games list looking for a game my laptop could actually run, my eye caught Return to Castle Wolfenstein. I hadn't played it for almost 10 years and I decided to give it a shot. Honestly, I was blown away with how well it has aged.

It's a shooter, but it's constructed very well. The levels are linear, but they also feel open. Lots of corridors and extra rooms to explore (2 or more secret areas for those who wish to find them). The shooting feels and sounds good. Each gun has it's own unique punchy sound and there's a huge variety. By the end of the game, you're carrying 11 different guns and 3 different explosives.

The story is cheesy and the voice acting is awful, but it's intriguing. If you've ever been fascinated with the Nazi's rumored interests in experimental weaponry, the paranormal and other weird things, RtCW takes that and runs with it.

My only complaint, is that some of the enemies are very bullet-spongy. It could take 5-6 rounds from the Paratrooper Rifle (the best in the game IMO) to take down a Paratrooper solider. Some enemies can even withstand more than one or two rounds from a sniper rifle. Annoying.

If you ever want to play an older" shooter
date: give RtCW a shot. You'll be pleasantly surprised.\n\nNote: Be sure to download the community patch that enables widescreen. It's a simple drag and drop installation and stable. I had no issues during my 8 hours with the game."

reviewText:
Return to Castle Wolfenstein.

General overview - average.
Graphics - 5/10
Sounds - 7/10
Mechanics - 5/10
Storyline - 4/10

This game was released in 2001 and naturally, the graphics look dated. There is a total of 7 linear missions to blast your way through and, as per all ID software games, there are hidden areas and goodies to be had. The sound is average and unfortunately the developers had the German soldiers speaking in German accented English. This is very dull compared to Wolfensteins occasional screams of 'mein laben!' and 'achtung!'.

Lucky there is a variety of guns to put to good use from your tradional dagger to pistols to machine guns to a tesla gun (among others). With all the options I found there was too much ammo in the game. The AI aren't completely stupid and will often hide and make you flush them out. They will also try to avoid grenades and will sometimes kick them back to you! They also have the ability to notice dead comrades and realise something is amiss and will either come searching for you or sound the alarm.

The story line is a little lacking making me feel they just chucked in a heap of fluff to try and get some length to the game. It does, however, take you everywhere from towns, snow peaks, large open areas and underground caverns (to name a few) so there is plenty to see.

Conclusion : Don't expect epic content from this game but if you'd like to take a crack at a classic then this would definately count.

Other notes : I would go through the process of creating a saved game. I would have to double check through the save menu to make sure it had since sometimes it didn't!

Return to Castle Wolfenstein falls short for most players with only its mediocre single-player.

reviewText:
Rating 6.5/10

What is it?
First Person Shooter

It is always difficult to review an older game in modern times. The question becomes does this game pass the test of time? ie. can you still have fun with this game today as you did when it first came out? And for me the answer is no. The first person shooter genre doesn't age as gracefully as other genres because the genre has been developed and refined so much over the years it becomes very easy to see all the flaws in older games.

This game has some serious flaws. First off the level design is big and often times very confusing. I love exploring large levels however when the environments look the same it feels like I'm running through a maze.

In addition the enemies feel like bullet sponges, at the same time enemies can fill you with an entire clip of their weapon in the span of a few seconds making saving and reloading your best weapon.

Then they added stealth in the game. Nothing says fast paced shooting like stealth. I love stealth but in doesn't work in this game. In fact the stealth mission they added to the game is possibly one of the worst implemenations of stealth I have ever seen. You have to do EXACTLY what the developers want you to do or else you will fail the mission leading to some very frustrating moments.

When I played this game when it first came out I really enjoyed it, however the game has aged horribly it terms of its gameplay and design. I actually think the original DOOM games are more fun and aged better than this game.

If you want some nostalgia and want to play this game then you might enjoy it, if you never played this game before your probably not going to like it at all.

Curator-esque Review
Has everything a Wolfenstein game should have: guns, girls, destructible chairs, zombies, random enemy spawns, creepy tombs, sausage, booby traps, castles, secret rooms, treasure, hard bosses, jump scares, occult horror, cool weapons, Wilhelm screams, spooky skeletons, and great level design.

Return to Castle Wolfenstein (RtCW) Review (Spoiler Free)

Story

As the Germans research any and every weapon that might give them an advantage over the allies during WWII, the SS's Paranormal Division stumbles upon the legendary tomb of Heinrich I at Castle Wolfenstein.  Immediately, the Allies send their best agents from the fictional Office of Secret Actions (OSA) to investigate the dig site at Wolfenstein.  Unfortunately, the OSA spies are captured and tortured.  Players take the role of B.J. Blaskowitcz, one of the captured spies.  After escaping Wolfenstein and the Heinrich archaeological dig deemed unimportant for the time being, the OSA send Blaskowicz on various missions to sabotage the Paranormal Divisions's other efforts across Europe.  As he gathers intelligence from his travels, B.J. uncovers the significance of Wolfenstein and the SS's plan for Heinrich I.

Gameplay

RtCW simultaneosly preserves and innovates its lineage.  This is a first person shooter with a great balance between gameplay and story.  Levels appear linear, but further investigation reveals secret levers, buttons, walls that can be destroyed, and other hidden switches that can lead to shortcuts, treasure to increase your score, or secret weapon caches.  Thus while the main goal is to complete the level, RtCW is a fun game just to look around in since you'll never know what you'll find.  In terms of shooting mechanics, their are crouch and lean mechanics giving the game a tactical approach.  Indeed, a stealth approach (silenced weapons, backstabs, minimal offensive fire) is advised and required for some portions of the game.  When the bullet start to fly though, there is a hefty arsenal of tools to employ.  SMG's, pistols, rifles, flamethrowers, rocket launchers, and other weaponry all have their uses.  Every weapons has different stopping power and ammo availibility, so you can choose to save your Thompson for tougher enemies or rely on the weaker but more available German weapons.  I almost consider RtCW to be survival horror at times because many of the supernatural enemies you will fight in the game take a lot of bullets to put down.  The segments with the X-Creatures are particularly tense in this regard.  There is also some puzzle solving and a few logic puzzles.

RtCW is a single player experience with the only game mode being the campaign.  There are mods that can make it co-op (which would be pretty cool) but I did not try them.  That being said, the five or so campaign missions themselves can take quite a while to complete.  Each mission has 4-7 chapters that took me on average a half-hour to complete probably.  The AI can be brutal at times even on normal and some sections are trial and error.  But there are some truly memorable moments here, such as moving through the Saxon tombs in the beginning of the game or later on infiltrating the X-Labs.

Design

Old games do not always translate well but I find RtCW to be one of the best.  The dialogue is great, the music bold and brash but also quite intimidating at times.  The tomb segments are some of my favorites, with dim lighting, armored skeletons, and eery noises.  You certainly do not start this game expecting it to get creepy but it sure does.  Enemies are well animated with only the death animations a little stiff for humans.  The Quake engine may be old, but boy does it hold up here.  Lighting and sound are both excellent and except for the occasional rough looking texture, the game has great atmosphere.

Final Thoughts

RtCW is a testament to the timelessness of shooters from around the turn of the century. Return to Castle Wolfenstein (RtCW) Review (Spoiler Free)

Story

As the Germans research any and every weapon that might give them an advantage over the allies during WWII, the SS's Paranormal Division stumbles upon the legendary tomb of Heinrich I at Castle Wolfenstein.  Immediately, the Allies send their best agents from the fictional Office of Secret Actions (OSA) to investigate the dig site at Wolfenstein.  Unfortunately, the OSA spies are captured and tortured.  Players take the role of B.J. Blaskowitcz, one of the captured spies.  After escaping Wolfenstein and the Heinrich archaeological dig deemed unimportant for the time being, the OSA send Blaskowicz on various missions to sabotage the Paranormal Divisions's other efforts across Europe.  As he gathers intelligence from his travels, B.J. uncovers the significance of Wolfenstein and the SS's plan for Heinrich I.

Gameplay

RtCW simultaneosly preserves and innovates its lineage.  This is a first person shooter with a great balance between gameplay and story.  Levels appear linear, but further investigation reveals secret levers, buttons, walls that can be destroyed, and other hidden switches that can lead to shortcuts, treasure to increase your score, or secret weapon caches.  Thus while the main goal is to complete the level, RtCW is a fun game just to look around in since you'll never know what you'll find.  In terms of shooting mechanics, their are crouch and lean mechanics giving the game a tactical approach.  Indeed, a stealth approach (silenced weapons, backstabs, minimal offensive fire) is advised and required for some portions of the game.  When the bullet start to fly though, there is a hefty arsenal of tools to employ.  SMG's, pistols, rifles, flamethrowers, rocket launchers, and other weaponry all have their uses.  Every weapons has different stopping power and ammo availibility, so you can choose to save your Thompson for tougher enemies or rely on the weaker but more available German weapons.  I almost consider RtCW to be survival horror at times because many of the supernatural enemies you will fight in the game take a lot of bullets to put down.  The segments with the X-Creatures are particularly tense in this regard.  There is also some puzzle solving and a few logic puzzles.

RtCW is a single player experience with the only game mode being the campaign.  There are mods that can make it co-op (which would be pretty cool) but I did not try them.  That being said, the five or so campaign missions themselves can take quite a while to complete.  Each mission has 4-7 chapters that took me on average a half-hour to complete probably.  The AI can be brutal at times even on normal and some sections are trial and error.  But there are some truly memorable moments here, such as moving through the Saxon tombs in the beginning of the game or later on infiltrating the X-Labs.

Design

Old games do not always translate well but I find RtCW to be one of the best.  The dialogue is great, the music bold and brash but also quite intimidating at times.  The tomb segments are some of my favorites, with dim lighting, armored skeletons, and eery noises.  You certainly do not start this game expecting it to get creepy but it sure does.  Enemies are well animated with only the death animations a little stiff for humans.  The Quake engine may be old, but boy does it hold up here.  Lighting and sound are both excellent and except for the occasional rough looking texture, the game has great atmosphere.

Final Thoughts

RtCW is a testament to the timelessness of shooters from around the turn of the century.  Despite it's age, it manages to capture the spirit of Wolfenstein and always amps up the action when you least expect it.  Grab your MP40 and return to Wolfenstein in this glorious reboot of the FPS that some consider pioneered the genre.

It could just be my computer but I get severe & random frame drops every now and again despite most of the game going at 60-90+ FPS.

The maps in the game are both linear with a few very small paths to find secrets & supplies & whatnot and somewhat open where objectives may have you do some bothersome backtracking. The backtracking really can be a bother since there aren't usually any visible indications on where to go next for anything. In some relatively open maps I had to do some running around to find where I had to go which I'm usually fine with until things like locked doors that have been passed by minutes ago only become unlocked with very little to no indication of the door being unlocked after an objective is reached on another side of the map happens.

Although the game is generally straightforward with its shooting there are stealth mechanics in the game, which seem pretty weak. At the very least it functions; crouch or walk up behind an enemy and use a suppressed gun or backstab with a knife to silently kill them while avoiding enemy detection. The problem is that it seems a bit out of place for a game that's generally all about being fast and shooty. The stealth is optional in most missions and I think for the most part there are times where detection is unavoidable.
After an enemy spots you it seems like headshots become almost non-existant when all enemies are aware of your presence. They don't die instantly when taking in a headshot or the spreadless-shots hitting the body instead of the head despite the reticle aimed at the face. Return to Castle Wolfenstein (RtCW) Review (Spoiler Free)

Story

As the Germans research any and every weapon that might give them an advantage over the allies during WWII, the SS's Paranormal Division stumbles upon the legendary tomb of Heinrich I at Castle Wolfenstein.  Immediately, the Allies send their best agents from the fictional Office of Secret Actions (OSA) to investigate the dig site at Wolfenstein.  Unfortunately, the OSA spies are captured and tortured.  Players take the role of B.J. Blaskowitcz, one of the captured spies.  After escaping Wolfenstein and the Heinrich archaeological dig deemed unimportant for the time being, the OSA send Blaskowicz on various missions to sabotage the Paranormal Divisions's other efforts across Europe.  As he gathers intelligence from his travels, B.J. uncovers the significance of Wolfenstein and the SS's plan for Heinrich I.

Gameplay

RtCW simultaneosly preserves and innovates its lineage.  This is a first person shooter with a great balance between gameplay and story.  Levels appear linear, but further investigation reveals secret levers, buttons, walls that can be destroyed, and other hidden switches that can lead to shortcuts, treasure to increase your score, or secret weapon caches.  Thus while the main goal is to complete the level, RtCW is a fun game just to look around in since you'll never know what you'll find.  In terms of shooting mechanics, their are crouch and lean mechanics giving the game a tactical approach.  Indeed, a stealth approach (silenced weapons, backstabs, minimal offensive fire) is advised and required for some portions of the game.  When the bullet start to fly though, there is a hefty arsenal of tools to employ.  SMG's, pistols, rifles, flamethrowers, rocket launchers, and other weaponry all have their uses.  Every weapons has different stopping power and ammo availibility, so you can choose to save your Thompson for tougher enemies or rely on the weaker but more available German weapons.  I almost consider RtCW to be survival horror at times because many of the supernatural enemies you will fight in the game take a lot of bullets to put down.  The segments with the X-Creatures are particularly tense in this regard.  There is also some puzzle solving and a few logic puzzles.

RtCW is a single player experience with the only game mode being the campaign.  There are mods that can make it co-op (which would be pretty cool) but I did not try them.  That being said, the five or so campaign missions themselves can take quite a while to complete.  Each mission has 4-7 chapters that took me on average a half-hour to complete probably.  The AI can be brutal at times even on normal and some sections are trial and error.  But there are some truly memorable moments here, such as moving through the Saxon tombs in the beginning of the game or later on infiltrating the X-Labs.

Design

Old games do not always translate well but I find RtCW to be one of the best.  The dialogue is great, the music bold and brash but also quite intimidating at times.  The tomb segments are some of my favorites, with dim lighting, armored skeletons, and eery noises.  You certainly do not start this game expecting it to get creepy but it sure does.  Enemies are well animated with only the death animations a little stiff for humans.  The Quake engine may be old, but boy does it hold up here.  Lighting and sound are both excellent and except for the occasional rough looking texture, the game has great atmosphere.

Final Thoughts

RtCW is a testament to the timelessness of shooters from around the turn of the century.  Despite it's age, it manages to capture the spirit of Wolfenstein and always amps up the action when you least expect it.  Grab your MP40 and return to Wolfenstein in this glorious reboot of the FPS that some consider pioneered the genre.

The first rule with Return to Castle Wolfenstein is that despite its title, it’s less a sequel and more a remake.  Why they called it ‘Return to’ when its not returning, unless they are remarking about you and I the gamer, returning to the series.  Then I guess it might make sense.

When it was released it made it to the consoles, because some people insist on not playing games as best as they could.  And for some strange reason the Xbox release got bonus content that the PC didn’t get.  Just one of life’s mysteries I guess.

I’ve read at various places that the multiplayer element of Return to Castle Wolfenstein was what really made the game.  And while it does sound like an interesting play mechanic, a sorta blend of Team Fortress and Counter-Strike, and there is even a guide to help you get it working again.  But I’m just too much of a hermit to play most multiplayer games out there.

So I played the single player, cause that’s my thing.  And it starts off similar to its predecessor, with you in a prison cell inside the dungeon of Castle Wolfenstein and a dead Nazi in front of you.  Now of course there is a little scripted sequence prior to this.  First you get a little information about why you are there and you get to learn about the Office of Secret Affairs or OSA.  Then you get another scripted sequence of just how that Nazi became a dead one, and what happened to your partner, Angent One.

Outside of the first two levels, and your escaping from the castle, that’s where the two games similarities end.  Return to Castle Wolfenstein goes on it’s own path and sends you around to many different locations, only to bring you back to the castle at the end to tie it all up.

Everything isn’t perfect however, the game has it’s issues.  Although mostly small and easily ignored.  Like when you die it often ignores your last quicksave and loads the last autosave instead, miner nuance really.  It also could use some more autosaves, instead of pretty much only at the start of the levels.  There might be one or two that autoave mid level, but I only ever noticed them happen at the start of a level.

So more than once I would me more than halfway into a level, having finished the first task, only to die and be sent all the way back to the start.  Maybe more of my own fault for not quicksaving more, but as a general rule games should autosave when an objective is complete, not just on map changes.

The AI combat is good, no enemies are too easy nor was anyone too tough.  I didn’t like just how tough the undead soldier/demon/zombie things were.  More than once I’d hit them square in the head and they would just keep coming.  Maybe its the games engine, but headshots should always be instant kills, with boss battles being acceptable deviations.

The game has a fair share of stealth levels, sometimes going so far as even being seen causing you to fail the mission.  This added with the ‘somewhat’ open worlds was the recipe for awesome.  And all things considered that is what this game is.  A fun Nazi killing trip around Germany.

The graphics could hold up better, perhaps someone out there are had a HD textures mod or something.  The audio, NPC AI, and basic gameplay mechanics are all decent enough to keep you entertained.  It’s not what I would call the best twelve year old game out there, but it certainly is a good one.

So I already have decent understanding of the story of this game. Heck, I know the whole story in general. The story is good: during the Second World War, you play as an American agent of some secret service who investigates certain activities of the fictional SS Paranormal Division. You operate behind enemy lines, your mate has fallen and the service refuses to send reinforcements; therefore, you stand alone. The story fits nicely in the whole Wolfenstein saga, and gives a nice thrill overall.

Graphics are good for a game which is roughly 14 years old. Gameplay doesn't have any serious shortcomings either; it is just your average first person shooter. Only thing I miss is the possibility to aim down the iron sights of non-scoped weapons. The setting is an extra plus for fans of the WW2-genre, with a touch of fantasy attached to it. Bonus points for feelings of nostalgia.

The only serious problem with this game is the initial inability to set the resolution higher than the default setting. Although that can be fixed by downloading and mounting a non-official patch of the game (link: http://www.markshan.com/knightmare/. Patch can be found under 'DOWNLOADS'. Extract all files in the ZIP-file in the Return To Castle Wolfenstein folder under SteamApps > commons.), it is an issue which prevents jumping right in, which some may find irritating, and should be adressed accordingly by Steam.

One more important thing: make sure to save your game regularly, as the game doesn't save automatically even after completing a level. Got me back to the beginning after three levels.

This game is okay and deserves to be recommended, but enthusiasts of nostalgia and the WW2-genre will find something valuable in Return To Castle Wolfenstein.

A pretty straightforward run & shoot Quake 3: Arena mod; get to an objective while killing off Nazi forces and abnormal looking enemies to keep alive. The game gradually gets tougher as you progress through the missions where new enemies who unnaturally aim better and have more powerful guns will start coming in.

It could just be my computer but I get severe & random frame drops every now and again despite most of the game going at 60-90+ FPS.

The maps in the game are both linear with a few very small paths to find secrets & supplies & whatnot and somewhat open where objectives may have you do some bothersome backtracking. The backtracking really can be a bother since there aren't usually any visible indications on where to go next for anything. In some relatively open maps I had to do some running around to find where I had to go which I'm usually fine with until things like locked doors that have been passed by minutes ago only become unlocked with very little to no indication of the door being unlocked after an objective is reached on another side of the map happens.

Although the game is generally straightforward with its shooting there are stealth mechanics in the game, which seem pretty weak. At the very least it functions; crouch or walk up behind an enemy and use a suppressed gun or backstab with a knife to silently kill them while avoiding enemy detection. The problem is that it seems a bit out of place for a game that's generally all about being fast and shooty. The stealth is optional in most missions and I think for the most part there are times where detection is unavoidable.
After an enemy spots you it seems like headshots become almost non-existant when all enemies are aware of your presence. They don't die instantly when taking in a headshot or the spreadless-shots hitting the body instead of the head despite the reticle aimed at the face. There are objectives where you can't allow the enemy to hit the alarm if you've been found which in this game is more annoying than it is fun. Fortunately objectives like those are incredibly minimal in number.

There are a chunk of weapons you can have in the game almost all practical one way or another. The only guns in the game I found to be useless are the two available pistols which all shoot very slowly and are generally weak

I could be observing this one wrong but the hitboxes for anything look like they go all over the place. When firing something with incredibly little spread aimed aproximately two feet away from an enemy they seem to take damage anyway.

Out of the 7 missions in the game (split into 3 or 4 parts each) there are only 2 boss fights (3 if you count that upgraded version of another enemy). All of them are incredibly easy to kill and are very anti-climactic when defeated, even the final boss.

It's still an overall simple and relatively short fast action Wolfenstein game (at least when you let it be that) so there's definitely fun to be had.
